subject: RE: [junit] Query on estimation
msgSnippet: well put! Rakesh ... From:	junit@yahoogroups.com on behalf of David Jackman Sent:	Fri 9/30/2005 3:53 PM To:	junit@yahoogroups.com Cc: Subject:	RE: [junit]
messageBody:
well put!

Rakesh


-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com on behalf of David Jackman
Sent: Fri 9/30/2005 3:53 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Cc:
Subject: RE: [junit] Query on estimation
I've been doing unit testing for years now on projects, and I've found
that there just isn't a good formula to use when attempting to estimate
how much time to factor in for unit testing. In my experience, most
people estimate the time to design and code their module and then want
to add an estimate for writing tests for that module once the design and
coding are finished. I've found two major drawbacks to this approach:
1) It will take longer to write the tests after the design and
coding are finished than it does to write the unit tests at the same
time design and coding are happening. This is because the module isn't
necessarily designed with tests in mind so it's harder to write tests
for portions of the code in isolation (i.e. the design doesn't allow
that code to be isolated). Another reason that writing tests takes
longer here is because there are naturally bugs in the design and coding
of the module that will be discovered when the tests are finally
written. This means that the time designated as "unit testing" in the
estimate will also be spent re-designing and re-coding. This highlights
the problem with testing only after the coding is finished (and the
reason testing as-you-go takes less time): the time spent coding to a
bad design is wasted time. It is better to discover the design flaw as
soon as possible so very little time is wasted on coding to the bad
design. Many design flaws aren't apparent until you start writing code
that calls your module (and the unit tests are the first thing that does
this), so it's better to have the tests going as early in the process as
possible.
2) There's a tendency for developers to view the time allocated for
testing as a schedule pad (since they didn't really want to spend time
testing anyway). When this happens, they allow the design and coding
portion of their schedule to take a bit longer then catch up by spending
less time writing tests. This is a problem for obvious reasons.

That said, you still have the issue of how best to estimate the schedule
for building your great product. For someone who is not already
experienced in unit testing and test driven development (TDD) practices,
I would recommend estimating the time to complete a module to be twice
what they would estimate taking without doing testing. This seems like
a lot of extra time, but it really isn't when you look at the entire
process for getting a product finished and out the door. In my
experience, developers estimating their time to complete a module
consider the time to design and code the module, and their estimate ends
there. In reality, once they've "finished" the module they will
continue to spend time coming back to the module to fix bugs found in
some QA process, which means the total time spent to build the module
includes their design+code time as well as all of the bug fixes. By
doubling the traditional estimate (which would have been just the
design+code time), you're allowing for the extra time to write the tests
and fix the bugs found by those tests. It will also allow some
additional time to learn about how best to do unit testing, which won't
happen with every project. Once a developer has completed a couple of
projects with testing, they will be better able to come up with
estimates that include the testing effort (which can be as accurate as
estimates can be for this sort of thing, and we all know there's a lot
of uncertainty here).

I would definitely recommend taking the time to train and convince your
team the best practices for writing tests and doing test driven
development. This includes the technical aspects of the testing
framework (JUnit) as well as the theoretical aspects of the discipline.
In my experience, some developers have a hard time with this and it
takes time for them to realize that you really can finish a project
faster when following these practices.

Well, that was rather long-winded. Hope the information you really
wanted is in there somewhere.
..David..



________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Rakesh Patel
Sent: Friday, September 30, 2005 12:39 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Query on estimation


Hi,

I have read more about unit testing than actually doing it so bear that
in mind - apparently, once the developers have got used to writing unit
tests, the time taken to write code+unit tests is shorter than just
writing the code. The reason being that you end up writing 'just enough'
to get the job done because you have tests.

Also, it is not recommended to split estimates into 2 parts like that.
Unit testing and code-writing are one task.

Hopefully, someone with more experience will back these comments up.

Cheers

Rakesh

-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
sachin.dholakia@...
Sent: 29 September 2005 09:31
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Query on estimation



Dear all,

I would like to use JUnits for a development project. Can somebody guide

how to estimate for unit testing using JUnits. There are 3 team members
out of 6 who aren't aware of JUnits.


Thanks & Regards,
Sachin Dholakia
